li: Java
Browse areas on the web site that require authentication. Verify that the browser displays that SSL is being used.
Examine the server configuration files. Review the web application server configuration files to make sure that SSL is properly configured and is being used.

Get valid certificates. Purchase a valid SSL certificate. You may purchase a valid SSL key from VeriSign, Thawte, or your web hosting provider. Follow the vendor's instructions for purchasing the SSL certificate. The certificate is usually a .cer file.
Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

Enable SSL on the web server. The exact instructions for enabling SSL are different for different web servers. Please, see the links at the bottom of this page for more information about enabling SSL on some common web application platforms.

Use SSL to protect the sensitive pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to enable SSL for all folders containing sensitive pages.

Redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages.
For information about using SSL on Apache Tomcat 6.0, please see http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-6.0-doc/ssl-howto.html
For information about using SSL on Java Application Server, please see http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/WebServices/appserv8-1.html
For information about using SSL on Java Application Server, please see http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/WebServices/appserv8-1.html
For information about using SSL with JBoss Web, please see http://docs.jboss.org/jbossweb/3.0.x/ssl-howto.html
For information about using SSL with Glassfish, please see http://javadude.wordpress.com/2010/04/06/getting-started-with-glassfish-v3-and-ssl/

p: SSL should be used to protect all pages that handle sensitive data to protect from eavesdropping attacks.
To verify that SSL is used:
Browse areas on the web site that require authentication. Verify that the browser displays that SSL is being used.
Examine the server configuration files. Review the web application server configuration files to make sure that SSL is properly configured and is being used.

The exact instructions for enabling SSL are different for different servers. Enabling SSL is a common task and is well documented for common web server platforms. Links at the bottom of this page lead to documentation that explains how to enable SSL on different platforms. There are some general guidelines that apply to different platforms:

Get valid certificates. Purchase a valid SSL certificate. You may purchase a valid SSL key from VeriSign, Thawte, or your web hosting provider. Follow the vendor's instructions for purchasing the SSL certificate. The certificate is usually a .cer file.
Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

Enable SSL on the web server. The exact instructions for enabling SSL are different for different web servers. Please, see the links at the bottom of this page for more information about enabling SSL on some common web application platforms.

Use SSL to protect the sensitive pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to enable SSL for all folders containing sensitive pages.

Redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages.

html:
Applies to

  • Java

What to Check For

Verify that SSL is used.

Why

SSL should be used to protect all pages that handle sensitive data to protect from eavesdropping attacks.

How to Check

To verify that SSL is used:

  1. Browse areas on the web site that require authentication. Verify that the browser displays that SSL is being used.

  2. Examine the server configuration files. Review the web application server configuration files to make sure that SSL is properly configured and is being used.

How to Fix

The exact instructions for enabling SSL are different for different servers. Enabling SSL is a common task and is well documented for common web server platforms. Links at the bottom of this page lead to documentation that explains how to enable SSL on different platforms. There are some general guidelines that apply to different platforms:

  1. Get valid certificates. Purchase a valid SSL certificate. You may purchase a valid SSL key from VeriSign, Thawte, or your web hosting provider. Follow the vendor's instructions for purchasing the SSL certificate. The certificate is usually a .cer file.

  2. Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

  3. Enable SSL on the web server. The exact instructions for enabling SSL are different for different web servers. Please, see the links at the bottom of this page for more information about enabling SSL on some common web application platforms.

  4. Use SSL to protect the sensitive pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to enable SSL for all folders containing sensitive pages.

  5. Redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages.

Additional Resources

  • For information about using SSL on Apache Tomcat 6.0, please see http://tomcat.apache.org/tomcat-6.0-doc/ssl-howto.html
  • For information about using SSL on Java Application Server, please see http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/WebServices/appserv8-1.html
  • For information about using SSL on Java Application Server, please see http://java.sun.com/developer/technicalArticles/WebServices/appserv8-1.html
  • For information about using SSL with JBoss Web, please see http://docs.jboss.org/jbossweb/3.0.x/ssl-howto.html
  • For information about using SSL with Glassfish, please see http://javadude.wordpress.com/2010/04/06/getting-started-with-glassfish-v3-and-ssl/

Java Communication Security Guidelines

  • Encrypt Communication Links
  • Protect Sensitive Data Over the Network
  • Use SSL
  • Use SSL for All Sensitive Pages
  • Use SSL When Transmitting Credentials
  • Use Valid SSL Certificates
  • Use Only Strong SSL Algorithms
  • Do Not Cache Sensitive Data
  • Do Not Place Sensitive Data in Parameters

Java Communication Security Checklists

  • Communication Links are Encrypted
  • Sensitive Data Is Protected Over the Network
  • SSL Is Used
  • SSL Is Used for All Sensitive Pages
  • SSL is Used When Transmitting Credentials
  • Valid SSL Certificates Are Used
  • Only Strong SSL Algorithms Are Used
  • Sensitive Data Is Not Cached
  • Sensitive Data Is Not Placed in Parameters
